Title: An entropy inequality
Content: Denote $H(p) = -p \log_2 p - (1-p)\log_2(1-p)$ [Shannon entropy]. It is well-known that $H$ is a concave function that increases on $(0,\frac{1}{2})$ and decreases on $(\frac{1}{2}, 1)$ . Let $\beta, \beta_1, \beta_2 \in (0,\frac{1}{2})$ be real numbers such that $ H(\beta_1) + H(\beta_2) = 2 H(\beta).$ Let $r$ be a positive real number such that all values $\beta_1 + r, \beta_2 + r,\beta + r$ are less than $\frac{1}{2}$ . How to prove the following inequality? $$ H(\beta_1 + r - 2\beta_1 r) + H(\beta_2 + r - 2\beta_2 r) \ge 2H(\beta + r - 2\beta r)$$ UPD: Why I know that this inequality holds? Because it follows from rather deep result in Kolmogorov complexity theory . But I hope there is a simpler proof of this fact:)
